{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3635005,"name":"Tio","username":"Tio","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/d2c977/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-24T14:16:00.972Z","cooked":"

Can anyone recommend a tutorial to use photonvision to control a swerve drive robot to go april tag.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-05-24T14:16:00.972Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":27,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":180.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502338,"topic_slug":"best-tutorial-on-using-photonvision-with-swerve-drive-to-drive-to-apriltags","display_username":"Tio","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28847,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/best-tutorial-on-using-photonvision-with-swerve-drive-to-drive-to-apriltags/502338/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3635028,"name":"Tom","username":"Tom_Neu","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_neu/{size}/222407_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-24T15:11:47.269Z","cooked":"

Disclaimer: This isn’t a full tutorial, just a conceptual overview.

Assuming you already have a command that drives your swerve drivetrain—typically based on joystick input (e.g., left stick X/Y for translation and right stick X for rotation)—you can repurpose that structure for autonomous AprilTag alignment using PhotonVision.

PhotonVision can provide the pose of an AprilTag relative to your robot. This gives you the positional error (in X, Y, and rotation) between your current pose and the target. You can then run a separate PID controller for each axis (X, Y, and rotation) to reduce those errors to zero.

Make sure the PID outputs are scaled to match your drive input expectations (e.g., between -1 and 1 if you’re mimicking joystick input). Once scaled appropriately, feed those outputs into your drive command in place of joystick values. This allows your robot to automatically drive toward and align with the AprilTag as if it were being manually controlled.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-05-24T15:11:47.269Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":169,"readers_count":168,"score":33.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502338,"topic_slug":"best-tutorial-on-using-photonvision-with-swerve-drive-to-drive-to-apriltags","display_username":"Tom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59306,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5554 - Alumni. Former head of software, strategy and development"},"post_url":"/t/best-tutorial-on-using-photonvision-with-swerve-drive-to-drive-to-apriltags/502338/2","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3635038,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-24T15:47:06.520Z","cooked":"

Here’s my take on the problem:

The major thing that I think is important to understand is that although any drive-to-pose logic depends heavily on correct pose estimation/localization, the two are separate processes.

In my opinion, the best approach is to hook up your vision system to the robot’s pose estimator. This can be complex, but with tools like PhotonVision, you can get a barebones 3D pose estimation tool running with minimal effort. If you’re using a CTRE generated swerve project, the drivetrain already has accessible methods to add vision estimates. Otherwise, refer to the docs on SwerveDrivePoseEstimator to setup full-field pose estimations. The end result of this step is a full-field pose estiamtion, so your robot knows where it is at all times. Even when you don’t see an AprilTag, the odometry based solely on the swerve modules is good enough to get a semi-accurate result.

To actually align to a known pose is relatively easy if you make the assumption that the robot always knows where it is. You could use a HolonomicDriveController to drive the robot to a given pose, or you could use something more along the lines of a Pathplanner-generated on-the-fly path to avoid static obstacles like the reef. The simplest solution is to use the HolonomicDriveController to make straight-line drive-to-point logic. Using the outputs from the drive controller, apply that chassis speed to the robot.

The advantages of using a full-field localization systems and separating the problem of drive-to-pose and pose estimation:

  • More control over target pose (doesn’t need to line up exactly with an AprilTag, instead can be anywhere on field - even in places where you don’t see a tag).
  • You don’t need to see an AprilTag (Although you should have your cameras mounted such that they can see the tag when near the target pose)
  • You can also adapt your algorithm to drive-to-pose to add more complexities without needing to also make changes affecting vision
  • You can use a full-field pose estimate to do other functionality, such as automatically running the intake motors if you’re near the intake station, or other semi-autonomous functions.
  • With separated vision and navigation, you can split the workload between multiple people who don’t need to worry about the other person’s requirements. The vision person gets vision running well, and the alignment person is free to just build alignment.

This method may be overkill, but it’s highly versatile and a basic implementation isn’t too hard to setup.

3414 Hackbots"},"post_url":"/t/best-tutorial-on-using-photonvision-with-swerve-drive-to-drive-to-apriltags/502338/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3635138,"name":"Ed Peters","username":"epeters1111","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/epeters1111/{size}/182731_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-24T18:58:42.803Z","cooked":"

I’m curious how accurate full field pose really is, and how people tune it.

This was our first year trying it using a Limelight with MegaTag2. We got the code working relatively easily, but in our school we don’t have a standing practice field. We set up and tear down in the lobby and do our best to position field pieces accurately.

We found our accuracy was frequently off by a few inches. Since this year’s challenge required pretty precise control, we really struggled to benefit from auto positioning.

We wound up not using auto scoring at all in our first match and rewriting our targeting to do image based positioning. We were able to tune that pretty well.

I’d love to understand full field positioning though. It seems powerful. How do you tune it?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-05-24T18:58:42.803Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":22.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502338,"topic_slug":"best-tutorial-on-using-photonvision-with-swerve-drive-to-drive-to-apriltags","display_username":"Ed Peters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56650,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/best-tutorial-on-using-photonvision-with-swerve-drive-to-drive-to-apriltags/502338/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3635227,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-24T21:42:54.297Z","cooked":"

We saw that there were definitely areas where full field pose estimation was less accurate than others. We had no special vision setup, but rather we ran 4 cameras at 320x240 - the lowest possible resolution for PV. By simulating possible locations on the robot for the cameras, we were able to find positions on the robot that gave us two “eyes” on the AprilTags, from different angles (with lots of skew) when we were aligned and close to the reef. This gave us three relatively distinct “zones” on the field:

  • Reef zone: this is the locations on the field where we’re within 6 feet from the reef. Here, we often see multi-tag estimates (which are pretty accurate) and solidly accurate single-tag estimates.
  • Intake station: locations near the intake station, where we see multiple reef tags, but from a distance away far enough such that we saw error values centered around 3-4 inches. This meant that we could align to the intake station, because we don’t need that much accuracy for intake align.
  • Everywhere else: Everywhere else, we infrequently saw pose estimates. This means that we relied heavily on module odometry for pose estimation, so these estimates are often off by nearly 8 inches.

It is true that there are some inaccuracies with full-field estimations, we didn’t find it problematic because we setup our cameras such that we get good pose estimations where it really matters.

The second aspect of full-field estimations is making sure that we weigh each pose estimation differently, depending on data about the estimate. I authored a post about this not that long ago that describes how I approached weighing estimates.
